articles.headline: Shutdown’s Pain Cuts Deep for the Homeless and Other Vulnerable Americans
articles.snippet: With the Department of Housing and Urban Development hit hard, subsidies for low-income renters have stopped and nonprofits are scrambling to avoid layoffs and cuts to support services.
articles.abstract: With the Department of Housing and Urban Development hit hard, subsidies for low-income renters have stopped and nonprofits are scrambling to avoid layoffs and cuts to support services.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ramona Wormley-Mitsis got welcome news in December: After years of waiting, the federal government had approved a subsidy that allowed her to rent a three-bedroom house, bracketed by a white picket fence to keep her two autistic sons from bolting into traffic.

articles.headline: Google Is Fined $57 Million Under Europe’s Data Privacy Law
articles.snippet: France penalized the company for not properly disclosing to users how data is collected across its services to present personalized advertising.
articles.abstract: France penalized the company for not properly disclosing to users how data is collected across its services to present personalized advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — After European policymakers adopted a sweeping  data privacy law last year, the big question was how regulators would use their newfound authority against the most powerful technology companies.

articles.headline: Deripaska and Allies Could Benefit From Sanctions Deal, Document Shows
articles.snippet: The Trump administration’s agreement to lift sanctions on the empire of the Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska would allow him to pay off substantial debt.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration’s agreement to lift sanctions on the empire of the Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska would allow him to pay off substantial debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Trump administration announced last month that it was lifting sanctions against a trio of companies controlled by an influential Russian oligarch, it cast the move as tough on Russia and on the oligarch, arguing that he had to make painful concessions to get the sanctions lifted.

articles.headline: China Transforms, and a Factory Owner Struggles to Follow
articles.snippet: Shao Chunyou rose from the assembly line to the boss’s office. Now the old recipes for success don’t work, and he must reinvent himself again.
articles.abstract: Shao Chunyou rose from the assembly line to the boss’s office. Now the old recipes for success don’t work, and he must reinvent himself again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shao Chunyou exemplifies the Chinese dream. Over three decades, he rose from an assembly line worker to an electronics business owner, following China’s rise from an economic backwater to the world’s No. 2 economy. He now owns two factories and employs over 2,000 workers.

articles.headline: What Made the TV Show ‘You’ a Hit? Netflix
articles.snippet: The show drew virtually no audience when it premiered on Lifetime in September. Now that it’s streaming, it’s a different story.
articles.abstract: The show drew virtually no audience when it premiered on Lifetime in September. Now that it’s streaming, it’s a different story.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout the fall, the producer Greg Berlanti was trying to save his cable drama “You.”

articles.headline: Chilling Davos: A Bleak Warning on Global Division and Debt
articles.snippet: An influential financier says investors should pay heed to growing risks and social tensions — a message resonating at the World Economic Forum.
articles.abstract: An influential financier says investors should pay heed to growing risks and social tensions — a message resonating at the World Economic Forum.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — As business and political leaders arrive in the Swiss Alps for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, a surprisingly alarming letter from an influential investor who studiously eschews attention has already emerged as a talking point.

articles.headline: How Huawei Wooed Europe With Sponsorships, Investments and Promises
articles.snippet: As the Chinese telecommunications giant faces scrutiny over its security, its careful cultivation of European governments and customers is at risk of unraveling.
articles.abstract: As the Chinese telecommunications giant faces scrutiny over its security, its careful cultivation of European governments and customers is at risk of unraveling.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When new employees join Huawei, they are given books about the Chinese telecommunications company’s achievements. One featured accomplishment is how the company has thrived in Europe.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: Supreme Court Revives Transgender Ban for Military Service
articles.snippet: By a 5-to-4 vote, justices temporarily stayed trial court decisions blocking the policy while litigation in the lower courts moves forward.
articles.abstract: By a 5-to-4 vote, justices temporarily stayed trial court decisions blocking the policy while litigation in the lower courts moves forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday granted the Trump administration’s request to allow it to bar most transgender people from serving in the military while cases challenging the policy make their way to the court.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Will Review New York City Gun Law
articles.snippet: It is the court’s first Second Amendment case in nearly a decade and most likely means the court will start exploring and perhaps expanding gun rights.
articles.abstract: It is the court’s first Second Amendment case in nearly a decade and most likely means the court will start exploring and perhaps expanding gun rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Tuesday that it would review a New York City gun law that limits residents from transporting their guns outside their homes, its first Second Amendment case in nearly a decade and a test of the court’s approach to gun rights after the arrival of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh in October.
